<panel type="success" popup-url="https://github.com/MarkBind/markbind/pull/2463#issuecomment-2002302198" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**53 :octicon-code-review:** (review on PR #2463)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 17 12:20:19]%%

> > 3. If I'm not wrong, the mock logger is shared among all the tests in a file, in other words, the mock logger's data is not resetting for every test and is actually accumulated. I am thinking of adding something like :
> > 
```
> > afterEach(() => ``{``
> >     jest.clearAllMocks();
> > ``}``);
```
> > 
> > 
> >     
> >       
> >     
> > 
> >       
> >     
> > 
> >     
> >   
> > to reset the logger to a clean state after every test. Might not be very useful for now but I think it is safer to do so, because issues might arise in the future (eg. checking mock.calls.length)
> 
> Added the `afterEach` teardown hook, @yucheng11122017 do please take a look (and sorry for doing this after your review)
> 
> Edit: after looking at some code on StackOverflow regarding this, it seems that they put the `jest.clearAllMocks()` method in a `beforeEach` hook instead of an `afterEach` hook. I think this makes a bit more sense in the edge case that this test suite runs after another test suite which didn't reset the mocks after the other tests were run.

Good catch! I agree with the use of `beforeEach` as I feel that this would ensure that the tests in the file are guaranteed to have cleared mocks before each test is run rather than depending on another test file to ensure that the mocks are cleared. Here's an example for clarity:

Assume test 1 and test 2 are in two separate files and are run sequentially,

In `beforeEach`:
Test 1 clear mocks -&gt; Test 1 runs -&gt; Test 2 clear mocks -&gt; Test 2 runs

In `afterEach`:
Test 1 runs -&gt; Test 1 clear mocks -&gt; Test 2 runs -&gt; Test 2 clear mocks

In the case of using `afterEach` you can see that the clearing of mocks relies on the previous test 1 to clear it, whereas in `beforeEach` if the Test 2 run fails because mocks were not cleared, it is easier to tell that the mocks are not cleared as the Test 2 file does not have the `beforeEach` teardown hook. This makes each test file responsible for the clearing of mocks for their own tests. 
</panel>

Thanks for starting with the Cypress tests for this feature @nseah21. I think this file can be renamed to something like `zoomView_diffstat.cy.js`. 

Apart from checking if the diffstat has rendered, we can also check:
1. if both green and red bars are rendered for a general commit with > 0 insertions and deletions.
2. if the contribution bar is not visible for empty commits with 0 insertions/deletions.
3. if the size of the green/red bars is proportional to the insertion/deletion size. I think a naïve way to do this is to check whether the green bar length is greater or less than the red bar length depending on the contribution size. 

@vvidday 
</panel>

%%[created at: 2023 Jun 25 15:04:38]%%

Hi @nseah21, your code changes look great for a first attempt at creating the GitHub style diffstat! 
However, since we prefer the contribution bar (cgit) style, let us start with that as our first/default.

The reason we prefer the cgit style is that we can reuse the same code we have for the contribution bars below each ramp chart for creating the diffstat as well.

https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/blob/3878389c8ea7891f12feeeb373c575d1003c496a/frontend/src/components/c-summary-charts.vue#L221-L242

While you can copy over the same code for the diffstat, I would suggest that we move out this contribution bars code outside of `c-summary-charts.vue` into a separate file called `c-stacked-bar-chart.vue` and generalize it to be used by both the contribution bars and the diffstat. @vvidday can give his thoughts as well.

We can discuss whether we want a toggle mode for the 2 styles in a separate PR, where we can make use of the current set of changes.

Feel free to reach out to us if you have any questions with the `c-stacked-bar-chart.vue` implementation and we will be glad to help!
</panel>

**Review Status:** COMMENTED

 The new changes look great @nseah21! I agree with David's comments and have a few more to add.

Regarding your questions,
For (1), according to prof's earlier comments, I think we should consider the average contribution size across the entire report.
> 2. The same scale should be used for all commits in a report (not just one author) so that a visual comparison is possible. A 100 line commit of person A should be the same length as that of person B.

For (2), I also think the length of the diffstat should scale linearly as it's easier to comprehend for users.

---

Also, I think we should avoid the use of default red-colored bars on the summary chart contribution bars so that they are not confused with the deletions bar in the commit diffstat. I'd suggest using a shade of blue as the default for contribution bars.

%%[created at: 2024 Feb 11 20:49:35]%%

Generally, it is recommended to not have two scrolls in the same direction as "double-scrolling" causes poor UX and leads to many errors. 

The current title component integration uses double-scrolling, and I foresee many bugs in the scrolling behaviour due to this. Have mentioned one of them below:

### Steps to replicate
* Scroll to the complete bottom using the left panel
* Scroll to the top from the right panel until you can see the full title again

### Result
* The left panel does not scroll along with the right one to show the left panel's topmost contents, but the title above it is shown
* The user cannot scroll to show the top contents of the left panel unless they scroll to the bottom again until the title is not seen
* The method to scroll the full view (to show/hide the title) and the left panel is the same, so it seems like the browser randomly picks which one to scroll.

We may have to discuss with Prof @damithc regarding alternative ways to design this. I'd recommend only having the title as part of the left Summary panel, to avoid any scrolling issues. 
</panel>

Thanks for taking this up @sopa301! 

Upon some research, it seems like various sources online have differing opinions on what size(s) of favicons should be used for websites. 
* While the original size we used (16x16) is considered one of the [standard sizes](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/internet-explorer/ie-developer/samples/gg491740(v=vs.85)?redirectedfrom=MSDN) that should work well for most browsers, it seems like larger sizes such as the 200x200 we are using now can be [scaled down correctly](https://stackoverflow.com/a/48646940/152266610) most of the time. 
* Also, our MarkBind docs site uses the same 200x200 `favicon.ico` file as the site header. 

Considering this, and that this will increase the clarity of the favicon, I think the larger `.ico` file should be okay.

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 27 18:54:10]%%

> @ckcherry23 i added a cypress test, but for some reason the test seems flaky - the scroll in the cypress window seems to randomly stop at the div before the highlighted one and sometimes it works fine. manually testing this behaviour outside of cypress, this issue seems to never occur. for now, i added some retries to the flaky test. if possible, could you help me see if this flaky behaviour can be replicated on your end? meanwhile i will continue investigating!

Hi @jonasongg, I've investigated the issue you're facing, and seems like it's a bug in our testing framework Cypress. [Using `scroll-behavior: smooth` in Cypress tests broke actionability](https://github.com/cypress-io/cypress/issues/3200) like `click()` and `check()` in an older version. Although there seems to have been a fix for that issue, there is probably an edge case occurring in our code that is causing the same issue. You can remove the scroll-behavior CSS and verify that your test case passes without retries, to ensure that this is the root cause of the error.

As a workaround, you can disable smooth scrolling for that particular element before starting the test, and enable it after the test is complete. You can refer to some solutions for this mentioned in [the same issue](https://github.com/cypress-io/cypress/issues/3200). 

It would be great if we didn't have to use retries for this test, as we would expect such a feature to work reliably. If there is no possible workaround for this, then perhaps we can disable the smooth-scrolling animation and opt for an instant scroll instead.

</panel>

1. [High priority] The chart zoom feature (selected using Ctrl/Cmd + click) does not work correctly when the timelines are optimised, i.e., the dates used for the zooming in are the same as the original dates instead of the optimised dates, which is misleading to the user.

3. [Discuss] When the report is grouped by repos, the various authors under the repo may have different timelines. This discrepancy may make it difficult to compare when different teammates are contributing relatively. We may want to make the timeline duration consistent across a repo group (@damithc). However, when grouping by authors, this doesn't matter. 
4. [Discuss] We may want to think of a more intuitive name for "Optimise timeline", because it is not immediately clear what this feature does to end users. I would suggest something along the lines of "Condense charts".

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 13 21:57:52]%%

**Describe the bug**
After creating a bug, if I try to update the title, it just shows an error.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Create a bug report.
2. Click on the 'Edit' button beside the title
3. Update the title text and click 'Save'.
4. Title does not get updated. Instead, it returns an error message:
```js
Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'data')
```

**Expected behavior**
The title gets updated based on newly entered title.

@jonasongg Based on the issue reported in #2164, can you investigate what went wrong and reopen a PR for this?

To the RepoSense team: 
Although the merged PR successfully implemented the required search-by-tag functionality with adequate test cases, it inadvertently broke unrelated functionality. This oversight occurred because the data seemed to be intended that way, leading to its unnoticed impact.

This is because our end-to-end tests mainly focus on testing features rather than data representation. To avoid this in the future, we could do the following:
* Data-driven testing: Add tests to check if the actual JSON data is being represented in the expected manner.
* Snapshot testing: Implement snapshot testing to ensure there are no visual regressions. 

</panel>

%%[created at: 2023 Jun 30 21:50:41]%%

I feel that currently, this component might be too tightly coupled with the two components that are using it (summary-charts and zoom), since it contains summary-charts specific implementation details (whether `filterBreakdown` is checked, and determining the colours for each file type) and zoom specific details (whether to show diffstat or not).

Ideally, this `stacked-bar-chart` component shouldn't have to know about these details, since its job is just to display/format the bars on screen. So for instance, it could take in something like
```typescript
bars: Bar[]

interface Bar ``{``
  width: number;
  color?: string;
  tooltipText?: string;
``}``
```
which is all the info it needs to display the bars, and it will contain just the code to parse that info into the UI component. Then, it will be up to the respective parent components to decide how to fulfill this "contract", i.e. how to get the info to pass into this component.

This way, we won't have to update this component every time there's a new component that uses it, and we keep the file-specific logic within the files itself (e.g. the different colours for each file type/`filterBreakdown` is only relevant in summary-charts, the `showDiffstat` is only used in zoom). 

Also in the future, when we add unit tests, it would be easier to test both the component (we can pass in a mocked bars array), and the parent component (we can test the function that generates the bars array) individually. With the current implementation, if there's a bug in the component, we might not know if the error came from the component itself, or the data being passed from its parent components.

</panel>

%%[created at: 2023 Oct 08 16:10:21]%%

Sorry for the delay. Did some investigation regarding this issue, will summarize for the benefit of others/future contributors as well:

- In the current code, `DailyCommit[]` is passed in place of `Commit[]` to the zoom view, which expects `Commit[]`. `Commit` is essentially a supertype of `DailyCommit` - it contains [two additional fields, `insertions` and `deletions`](https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/blob/master/frontend/src/types/types.ts#L30).
- This means that anytime code in the zoom view (provided the zoom view is generated by this method call, which happens when a user clicks on a commit in the ramp with granularity set to day/week as outlined above & in the video), accesses these properties (`commit.insertions`/`commit.deletions`), something might break
- There are currently 2 bugs that I found with the zoom view that is generated from this action,
  - Sorting by lines of code in the zoom view doesn't work properly, since it sorts by `commit.insertions`, which would be undefined (https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/blob/master/frontend/src/views/c-zoom.vue#L191)
  - The message body of commits aren't shown, as can be seen in the video in the earlier comment. This might be a potential regression caused by #1866, as the `isOpen` property that enables the toggling of message bodies is only added to the commits in `user.commits` instead of `user.dailyCommits`. (https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/pull/1866/files#diff-5419037f2fc8c426a6a54e0614ee8033d10e16426d30573486c27e5811036869)

The fix you introduced fixes the first bug, but not the second. I'm actually not sure what the purpose of the original line `zoomUser.commits = user.dailyCommits;` is. It seems that by removing the line (and leaving `zoomUser.commits` alone), both of the above bugs don't occur. 

Given that these bugs are due to existing code and that this fix technically changes logic but doesn't fully fix the existing bugs, it's my preference that we don't introduce the new adding of insertions/deletions in this PR. IMO we can just do the original unsafe typecast (`as Commit[]`) and leave a comment warning that this typecast is unsafe, and file the current bugs as an issue to be fixed in a separate PR, since fixing those are out of the scope of migrating the file to TypeScript. I think this is just one of the instances where converting files to TypeScript help us uncover existing bugs.

The above approach is just my preference - please let me know if you have any thoughts on it (other reviewers please feel free to chime in!)
</panel>

Minor thing about the commit message body: try to follow the recommended format [(more details)](https://se-education.org/guides/guidelines/PRs.html#submitting-a-pr)
```
``{``current situation``}`` -- use present tense

``{``why it needs to change``}``

``{``what is being done about it``}`` -- use imperative mood

``{``why it is done that way``}``

``{``any other relevant info``}``
```
Some parts might seem obvious/redundant especially for smaller changes, but it's good to develop the habit for future PRs. For example, the body could be:
```
Fix typo in Setting Up page

The command given in the developer guide for checking the local Node.js
version is `npm -v`, which displays the version of npm instead.

Let's replace the command with `node -v`, which correctly displays the

%%[created at: 2024 Feb 17 14:15:23]%%

This is more of a Javascript "gotcha", but the catch block here doesn't catch any errors thrown by the promise chain. This is because the code doesn't wait for the promise to fulfill, and so the `fetch` function returns before the error is thrown asynchronously.

For example, if you try running this code:
```javascript
function f() ``{``
  return Promise.reject("Error");
``}``

try ``{``
  f()
    .then(() => ``{``
      console.log("Success");
      return 1;
    ``}``)
``}`` catch (err) ``{``
  console.log(`Error inside try catch block: $``{``err``}```);
``}``
```
You'll see that the statement inside the `catch` block never runs.

The two options we have are:
1) Using `.catch` (this makes the outer `try...catch` redundant)
```javascript
function f() ``{``
  return Promise.reject("Error");
``}``

try ``{``
  f()
    .then(() => ``{``
      console.log("Success");
      return 1;
    ``}``)
    .catch((err) => ``{``
      console.log(`This runs and catches the error: $``{``err``}```)
    ``}``)
``}`` catch (err) ``{``
  console.log(`This code still never runs: $``{``err``}```);
``}``
```

or 

2) Using `async/await`, which forces everything after await to wait for the promise to be fulfilled. So we can use the `try...catch` here:
```javascript
async function f() ``{``
  return Promise.reject("Error");
``}``

try ``{``
  await f()
  console.log("Success")
``}`` catch (err) ``{``
  console.log(`Now this runs: $``{``err``}```);
``}``
```
</panel>

Thanks for your work on this @sopa301!

Just wanted to highlight some things about the usage of `v-html`: There are some pretty important security concerns we need to be mindful of when using this, since rendering HTML that's partly controlled by users has the potential to lead to XSS vulnerabilities.

Reference: [Vue's docs](https://vuejs.org/guide/essentials/template-syntax.html#raw-html) and [React's equivalent](https://react.dev/reference/react-dom/components/common#dangerously-setting-the-inner-html) (React even deliberately named their property `dangerouslySetInnerHTML`)

Did some reading and it seems like it's OK in this case, as the library we're using (Markdown-it) [claims to output safe HTML as long as the raw HTML option is disabled (which it is by default)](https://github.com/markdown-it/markdown-it/blob/master/docs/security.md). Just wanted to highlight this point to make sure we are mindful of it if we want to introduce any more advanced features like custom styling in the future.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 11 21:17:15]%%

Since the non-null assertion operator is ignored during runtime, this method will throw an error if it is actually called when `this.filteredUser` is undefined.

It is true that in the current logic flow of our code, `this.filteredUser` will not be undefined (since you return early in `created()`), however there is no guarantee that this behaviour will be maintained in the future (e.g. If a developer mistakenly calls `updateFileTypes` before the return statement in `created`, or in another part of the code before `created` is run).

Hence it might be better (more type safety) to handle the undefined case explicitly instead - let me know what you think about this!

Related eslint rule that explains why using `!` might not be super ideal: https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/no-non-null-assertion/
</panel>

Is there a need to differentiate the `update-selected-file-types-hash` and `update:selectedFileTypes` emits? I personally feel that it might be okay to remove the `update-selected-file-types-hash` emit since this component doesn't need to know about the concept of hashes at all - it can just emit `update:selectedFileTypes` whenever the selectedFileTypes is updated/changed, and let the parent component decide what to do in response to that (which might include updating the hash).

For example, in c-summary, we listen to the emit and run the `getFiltered` method, but we run it _in repsonse to the checkedFileTypes changing_, rather than in response to needing to update the selected file types hash (updating the hash is one of the things done in `getFiltered`, among others).
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 11 20:56:06]%%

&lt;!--
  Before opening a new issue, please search existing issues:  https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues
-->

### What feature(s) would you like to see in RepoSense
&lt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of the feature.
-->
With https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2002 being worked on, it would be beneficial to add lint rule(s) to enforce typescript functions to have explicit return type annotations. This will ensure that future additions comply with the existing coding standard, and enforce uniformity across the codebase.

### Is the feature request related to a problem?

&lt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of what the problem is.
  Ex. I have an issue when [...]
-->
If this is not added, future functions might omit explicit return types, which would result in inconsistency across the frontend codebase.

### If possible, describe the solution

&lt;!--
  Here would be a good place to talk about the solution or the
  approach that can be taken.
-->
Add lint rule(s) to enforce explicit return types for functions. Example: https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/explicit-function-return-type/
We should make sure that the linter works for both raw `.ts` files and for TypeScript code inside `.vue` files. This rule should of course be added after the rule has been enforced across the existing code base (i.e. after #2002 is finished & closed).

Additionally, since this will be enforced as a rule, please also **update the style guide in the DG** to specify this rule.

### If applicable, describe alternatives you've considered

-->

%%[created at: 2024 Jan 31 09:42:34]%%

for discussion: since the builder is so tightly coupled with `RepoConfiguration`, would it make sense for the builder to hold a `RepoConfiguration` and build directly into it? This would save us the duplicated fields and boilerplate copies that seem error-prone. 

I think the Oracle [blog post](https://blogs.oracle.com/javamagazine/post/exploring-joshua-blochs-builder-design-pattern-in-java#:~:text=Bloch's%20Builder%20pattern%20can%20be,for%20a%20missing%20language%20feature.&text=The%20Builder%20pattern%2C%20which%20is,complex%20objects%20step%20by%20step.) also criticizes this duplication - in our case it seems very unlikely that we'd need the Builder for other objects.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Jan 31 20:05:22]%%

That's reasonable! I don't think we currently have any builder re-use (since this wouldn't have been possible with the constructors), but it seems possible that we might want to keep a builder for several `RepoConfiguration`s. It also seems like Java's `clone` is a bit of a slippery slope, so it might be unfortunately that this is the best we can do.

A small improvement might be to treat RepoConfiguration's constructor as a copy constructor:
```java
private RepoConfiguration(RepoConfiguration config) ``{``
    ...
``}``
```
so that we can at least get rid of the duplicaiton in the builder fields.
</panel>

<panel type="success" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/pull/2078#discussion_r1477318883" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**20 :octicon-code-review:** (review on PR #2078)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Feb 04 22:03:09]%%

Yes, my concern was that in setting booleans for example, we might be violating downstream assumptions about what combinations of fields were previously not possible (disallowed by the constructors), but are now possible.

Unfortunately since these assumptions are mostly implicit, we can't know for sure, without tracing through the whole pipeline, so I think we can do with just the location check for now. Minimally, existing Builder invocations should still work, and if fields interfere undesirably, we can fix them incrementally.
</panel>

You could probably do the construction of the names within the builder. Null checks are okay, my previous comment on optionals was more to set `displayName` etc to be optionals rather than using them just for the control flow. As long we make sure that the field is eventually set before the object is built, nulls seem fine to use.

> If so, I believe that this might unintentionally result in aliasing issues.

Also regarding aliasing, I realized `RepoConfiguration` instances would still share non-primitive fields which could still cause undesirable aliasing issues. We could possibly reset the RepoConfiguration instance when `build` is called, to avoid this.

> "Reflective" access is required to assert the type of exception thrown by any of the Throwable* interface is indeed of the correct type

1. Could you describe why the reflective access is required? Specifically, is there a situation in which it is possible for `new Fail&lt;>(throwable).getExceptionClass().isInstance(throwable)` to be false?

> there is an implicit assumption that the user knows that the type of exception stored within the instance is of the original exception type and that the flatmap should not change the exception type into something that is not a subclass of the original exception type

2. Do you mean that we aren't currently checking for this but we expect that the user maintains this discipline? I think this is not in general very realistic and in most cases would require big refactors of exceptions to make sure they can compose.  Scala ZIO has the expressivity of sum types so the handling of composed exceptions and exception handling is made much more natural. Maybe a compromise is to assert that flatMaps are done only with `CannotFailException`s, so exceptions need to be handled promptly. Java technically also has tuple types that we might be able to use to patch together exception composition, but that would get very messy quickly. What do you think?
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2141" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**66 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #2141: Use optionals for return values that may be null to enforce a client check)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 04 02:16:27]%%

&lt;!--
  Before opening a new issue, please search existing issues:  https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues
-->

### What feature(s) would you like to see in RepoSense
&lt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of the feature.
-->

A large number of getter functions have optional return semantics - the return value might be null if the field is uninitialized or not applicable. The problem is often that it's hard to know if a check is necessary without having the client know about the underlying details of the initialization logic. 

https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/blob/bbb2f694a74d0dc1dea9084ad47b25bcd0bb42cb/src/main/java/reposense/model/ConfigRunConfiguration.java#L44-L67

Not all nulls necessarily bad however. In some cases like this:

https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/blob/bbb2f694a74d0dc1dea9084ad47b25bcd0bb42cb/src/main/java/reposense/model/AuthorConfiguration.java#L165-L178

the scope of the nulls are only within a function, which does not suffer from the same issue of having to reason about the presence of a value.

Java `Optionals` are a good way to deal with this pattern, by enforcing a client check when a return value may not be present. This has both the effects of minimizing programmer error and helping document the intended nature of function return values. Ideally, return values that are not `Optional` are guaranteed to be present.

While this problem is not limited to getter functions, this would be a good place to start this refactor, and consider other instances on a case-by-case basis.

</panel>

I believe I omitted it at the time to avoid having to remember to fix documentation if/when we decide to adjust the limits, but the benefits of clarity from including it in the documentation is probably greater than the cost.
- There exists an example of the file size limit column in the example [repo-config.csv](https://reposense.org/ug/repo-config.csv) in the section. Do you think this is sufficient?
- That makes sense. Perhaps something like `If file analysis is not skipped, files exceeding the file size limit will be marked as ignored and only the file name and line count will be reflected in the report.`
- I believe the + denotes an overridable column. The file size limit in `repo-config.csv` can override the one specified in the standalone config.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2023 Dec 23 03:39:25]%%

&lt;!--
  Before opening a new issue, please search existing issues:  https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues
-->

### What feature(s) would you like to see in RepoSense
&lt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of the feature.
-->

The current implementation of the `RepoConfigCsvParser::processLine` method exhibits nesting, in the handling of file size limit logic. This nesting reduces the code's readability and maintainability. As per the [CS2103T - Avoid Deep Nesting](https://nus-cs2103-ay1819s1.github.io/cs2103-website/se-book-adapted/chapters/codeQuality.html#avoid-deep-nesting) code quality guideline, let's refactor `processLine` avoid this arrowhead style code.

![image](https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/assets/50147457/c5924f92-8a97-4259-9a76-92a525c069fd)



</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues/2076" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**65 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #2076: Refactor RepoConfiguration to simplify constructor complexity)
</div>

%%[created at: 2023 Dec 23 10:57:02]%%

&gt;!--
  Before opening a new issue, please search existing issues:  https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/issues
-->

### What feature(s) would you like to see in RepoSense
&gt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of the feature.
-->

I propose the implementation of the Builder pattern for complex configuration classes in RepoSense, such as [`RepoConfiguration`](https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/blob/master/src/main/java/reposense/model/RepoConfiguration.java). This pattern would enhance code readability, maintainability, and ease future modifications.


### Is the feature request related to a problem?

&gt;!--
  Provide a clear and concise description of what the problem is.
  Ex. I have an issue when [...]
-->

The current implementation of some classes, like `RepoConfiguration`, involve constructors with a large number of parameters (the largest constructor has 18 parameters) and multiple overloaded versions. This complexity makes the code difficult to understand and maintain, increasing the likelihood of errors such as mixing up order of parameters and hindering contributions from new developers.


```
    public RepoConfiguration(RepoLocation location, String branch, List<FileType> formats, List<String> ignoreGlobList,
            long fileSizeLimit, boolean isStandaloneConfigIgnored, boolean isFileSizeLimitIgnored,
            List<CommitHash> ignoreCommitList, boolean isFormatsOverriding, boolean isIgnoreGlobListOverriding,
            boolean isIgnoreCommitListOverriding, boolean isFileSizeLimitOverriding, boolean isShallowCloningPerformed,
            boolean isFindingPreviousAuthorsPerformed, boolean isIgnoredFileAnalysisSkipped,
            List<String> ignoredAuthorsList, boolean isIgnoredAuthorsListOverriding, String extraOutputFolderName) ``{``
```

### If possible, describe the solution

&gt;!--
  Here would be a good place to talk about the solution or the
  approach that can be taken.
-->

Adopting the Builder pattern for these classes will simplify object creation, enhance code clarity, and provide a flexible approach to object construction. This pattern is particularly beneficial for classes with numerous parameters and complex initialization logic.

### If applicable, describe alternatives you've considered

&gt;!--
  Let us know about other solutions you've tried or researched.
-->

Overloaded constructors or factory methods are alternatives, however in my opinion, they don't offer the same level of organization and extensibility as the Builder pattern, especially for classes with a high number of optional parameters.

While it's true that the Builder pattern is often used for building different immutable objects using the same building process, its applicability extends beyond that. In our case, the primary goal is to address the complexity arising from numerous constructor parameters and overloads. In my opinion, the Builder pattern not only streamlines the creation of objects but also enhances code readability and maintainability. It provides a clear and flexible way to construct objects, especially when the number of parameters is large and not all of them are required at once. Moreover, it supports future extensibility by allowing easy addition of new parameters without cluttering the constructor or requiring numerous overloaded constructors. Thus, even if immutability is not the primary concern, the Builder pattern can significantly improve the manageability of complex class construction in RepoSense.

### Additional context

&gt;!--
  Is there anything else that can be added about the proposal?
  You might want to link related issues here if you haven't already.
-->

In a previous PR #1942, the Builder pattern was implemented for the `CliArguments` class, following Bloch's Builder pattern as detailed in an [Oracle blog post](https://blogs.oracle.com/javamagazine/post/exploring-joshua-blochs-builder-design-pattern-in-java#:~:text=Bloch's%20Builder%20pattern%20can%20be,for%20a%20missing%20language%20feature.&text=The%20Builder%20pattern%2C%20which%20is,complex%20objects%20step%20by%20step.). This approach not only made `CliArguments` easier to extend but also resolved issues related to complex constructor initialization. This can be used as a reference on how to implement the builder pattern. Given this positive outcome, applying the Builder pattern to other complex classes within RepoSense could similarly improve the project's code quality and developer experience.


</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/12466" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**234 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #12466: Clarify masquerade mode in docs )
</div>

%%[created at: 2023 Jun 05 18:46:29]%%

The [docs](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/development.html#logging-in-to-a-teammates-instance) on masquerade mode is unclear on what username is on the development server 

`When logged in as administrator, masquerade mode can also be used to impersonate instructors and students by adding user=username to the URL e.g http://localhost:8080/web/student/home?user=johnKent.`

Developers who want to use masquerade mode have to ensure that the`username`  is the email address used to verify the user e.g (person@x.com) when signing up mock instructors. Username such as jack (for google id jack@example.com) would not work as the username.

![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/25302138/cff2d547-3e57-4a12-b67d-0904f9245976)
Signed up jack@example.com as instructor, which is also used as google id

Incorrect username used (jack)

![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/25302138/0744fbfc-7c36-4b6d-84a1-a877d6c1f2e3)
Correct username used (jack@example.com)

</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 21 21:35:51]%%

**Description of feature/enhancement**
Existing JSON test data used for tests is in the format for the current noSQL database. Migrating each JSON file by hand can be tedious due to the foreign key relationships enforced by SQL and any other attribute changes. This can be solved by using a user script to migrate these files instead


**Proposed Usage**
1. Specify JSON file to migrate, and create migrated file in same directory as JSON file
2. Create a folder to place JSON files to migrate and migrate all JSON files

Comments on what would be easier to use to use is welcome
</panel>

Cedric, I have improved the IT and have checked `DataBundleLogicIT.json` to ensure that there is indeed, some FeedbackSession, FeedbackQuestion, FeedbackResponse, FeedbackResponseComment and DeadlineExtension linked to the `session1InTypicalCourse` course. I can confirm that the cascading works.

To be honest, it's a little wonky. I retried and removed `@OnDelete(action = OnDeleteAction.CASCADE)` from the entity classes that I have added and only removing `@OnDelete(action = OnDeleteAction.CASCADE)` from FeedbackQuestion results in the IT passing. The ones in FeedbackSession are required. i.e.,:

![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/46486515/a35ed19b-52b5-4888-b188-e06fad1ab93c)

For clarity ([source](https://docs.jboss.org/hibernate/orm/6.4/userguide/html_single/Hibernate_User_Guide.html#pc-cascade-remove)):

> 6.15.3. CascadeType.REMOVE
The CascadeType.REMOVE allows us to remove a child entity along with the parent one. Traditionally, Hibernate called this operation delete, that’s why the org.hibernate.annotations.CascadeType provides a DELETE cascade option. However, CascadeType.REMOVE and org.hibernate.annotations.CascadeType.DELETE are identical.

Also for reference:
`@OnDelete(action = OnDeleteAction.CASCADE)` is used to specify the `ON DELETE CASCADE` action at the database level, ensuring that the database itself enforces the cascading delete behavior.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2023 Jul 16 23:19:43]%%

```suggestion
### Masquerading as another user

Masquerade mode is a feature that enables the admin to log in as mock instructors/students for testing and situations where masquerading as another user is applicable.

Essentially, when you are logged into the administrator account, you will be able to conveniently and directly access the other instructor/student accounts. When in masquerade mode, you should see a `(M)` at the top right of the page you are on.

**Note**:
If you decide to use port `8080` for the following steps below, make sure you have run `npm run build` in your project root. For more information, refer to [Building front-end files](#building-front-end-files). Else, you may use port `4200` which is TEAMMATES' frontend URL.

To prepare for _masquerade mode_, do the following:

- Log in as an administrator via http://localhost:4200/web/admin/home.
  - For more information, refer to the [Logging in to a TEAMMATES instance](#logging-in-to-a-teammates-instance) section above in this document.
- Create a new instructor by filling in the Name, Email, and Institution fields in the form provided. Once done, click on _Add Instructor_, followed by _Add_ under the **Action** column.
  - Copy the link address from the **_join link_**.
- Log out from the administrator account. Use the link you copied in the previous step and paste it into your browser's search bar. Enter the new account's email and register for the course.
  - Now, the registration is !!completed!! and we have a new account that we can masquerade as.
- Lastly, log out from the current account and log back in as an administrator and follow the rest of the steps below.

To masquerade as an **_instructor_**:

- Use the instructor's path `/web/instructor/home` with the instructor's email appended as a query parameter, e.g., `http://localhost:4200/web/instructor/home?user=kelvin@gmail.com`.
- For convenience, http://localhost:4200/web/instructor/home?user=INSTRUCTOR_EMAIL. Double click on `INSTRUCTOR_EMAIL` to replace it with the instructor's email.

To masquerade as a **_student_**:

- Use the student's path `/web/student/home` with the student's email appended as a query parameter, e.g., `http://localhost:4200/web/student/home?user=janethestudent@gmail.com`.
- For convenience, http://localhost:4200/web/student/home?user=STUDENT_EMAIL. Double click on `STUDENT_EMAIL` to replace it with the student's email.
```
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**127 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #12679: Copying feedback session: Name for copied session should not be whitespace)
</div>

%%[created at: 2023 Dec 24 11:45:34]%%

**Steps to reproduce**

1. Head to **Sessions** page.
2. On any course, click on **Copy**.
3. You should see this that the `Name for copied session*` has the same name as the Session you clicked **Copy** on. Now, clear the text input and this is what you will get below.
![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/46486515/8284c9b1-6414-4832-95fe-28db8ff935ce)

Now, let's try to add a whitespace. Validation passes i.e., There is a value for the copied session's name and it is a whitespace.

![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/46486515/ffe713a1-0015-43fb-844c-afe0e429e43c)

**Expected behaviour**

Whitespace should not be allowed for the copied session's name. Input validation should not allow whitespaces.

**Actual behaviour**

Converse of the above expected behaviour, i.e., Currently, whitespace as name is allowed and this happens after clicking on Copy:
![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/46486515/ce70e78a-7869-4e7c-a093-8753a2db2476)

This is validated on the client side. However, we should validate on the form first.

**Additional info**

Motivation for this issue from a PR: https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/pull/12670#issuecomment-1868207324

Proposed Solution:
1. You may look at this link on form validation: https://www.javatpoint.com/angular-form-validation-no-whitespace-allowed
2. Refer to this file in the codebase: `src\web\app\pages-help\session-links-recovery\session-links-recovery-page.component.ts`, there is an example on how validation is done L39, and you may use the above link in Point 1 to help you too.
And this is the page (http://localhost:4200/web/front/help/session-links-recovery):
![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/46486515/65af0787-2123-457b-9785-0267de1cb406)
To get to the above page, once you're logged in, in the navbar, click on Help -&gt; Recover Session Links -&gt; Hit on Submit without any input.

---

Let us know if you have any question.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 19 01:03:10]%%

From my understanding, the feature branch will only be merged after the migration is completed, right? Is this no longer the case? Assuming this is still the case, the script should not be used anymore when this is merged so I was not too careful on this. This was mainly placed there to prevent compilation errors. 😅

Regardless, I did specifically choose `APPROVED` because it does in fact correspond to `registeredAt` being null. What you are describing, where `registeredAt` is non-null and an account has been created, actually corresponds to `REGISTERED`.

There was also a discussion on this in the issue. It was long ago though, so maybe you missed it. Just in case, see:
- https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/11878#issuecomment-1173783073
- https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/11878#issuecomment-1173803204
- https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/11878#issuecomment-1173816614

Of course, there is the case where it is set to `APPROVED` when it should actually in fact be `REGISTERED`, but I felt it was not a big problem because of the assumption above, and because the account was already created so the account request could then already be ignored.

Still, I can try to change this so that it is more accurate by making it such that it is `APPROVED` if `registeredAt` is null or `REGISTERED` otherwise, instead of being default `APPROVED` always. This way, it should be correct even if migration is done after the feature branch is merged. In order for the other PR that depends on this to be submitted, let's merge this first; I will make this change to the migration script in a separate PR. I hope this is okay, @EuniceSim142 
</panel>

**Review Status:** CHANGES_REQUESTED

Thanks for proposing your changes @cedricongjh . Perhaps we should update the unit tests too, such that it fails with the old code, but passes with your proposed changes. If this code is the cause of the issue, I think your changes should be mostly okay, albeit with a few nits.

However, are we actually certain that this is the actual cause of the issue? It has been a while since I've worked on this project so correct me if I am wrong. I do agree that the current code updates the deadline maps in the `FeedbackSessionAttributes` object in memory. However, doesn't the `FeedbackSessionsDb::updateFeedbackSession` method load the `FeedbackSession` from the database (`FeedbackSessionsDb.java` line 207 `... getFeedbackSessionEntity ...`) before comparing (`FeedbackSessionsDb.java` line 221 onwards `boolean hasSameAttributes ...`)? Unlike the one in the memory, the one from the database should not have been updated yet at that point in time that we are checking if the attributes have changed.

In other words, I do not think we are comparing the updated feedback session with the feedback session in memory (with already updated deadline maps, which would be the same). I think we are actually comparing the updated feedback session with the feedback session in storage (with still unchanged deadline maps, which would be different). If so, I think the current code should not cause the bug, right? I think that's why the unit tests pass (`testUpdateFeedbackSessionsStudentDeadlinesWithNewEmail` and the instructor one). That is unless the unit tests are wrong, but they do not look wrong, at least to me.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Jan 28 01:41:57]%%

If we want to do this, I think we can delete in batches (unless there's a reason why we're not doing that). I think it would be something like this:

```suggestion
        CriteriaDelete<Section> cd = cb.createCriteriaDelete(Section.class);
        Root<Section> sRoot = cd.from(Section.class);
        Join<Section, Course> sJoin = sRoot.join("course");
        cd.where(cb.equal(sJoin.get("id"), courseId));
        HibernateUtil.createMutationQuery(cd).executeUpdate();
```

We may need to add a method in `HibernateUtil` to call `Session::createMutationQuery`.

See also:
- [java - How to delete by criteria in hibernate? - StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/a/54548571)
- [Criteria Update/Delete – The easy way to implement bulk operations with JPA2.1](https://thorben-janssen.com/criteria-updatedelete-easy-way-to/)
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 23 23:43:24]%%

I know it's in the design doc, but after thinking about it further, even though we're getting only the pending account requests internally, I think we can just keep it as `ResourceURIs.ACCOUNT_REQUESTS`, with the URI suffix without `/pending` at the end. The REST resources are still account requests, even though they are pending.

Since the status is a property of the account request resource, I think it would conventionally be a query parameter, like in URLs with filters. (Not that I am saying you should add it as a query parameter though. The default behaviour we agreed on is to get account requests that are pending, so I think a status query parameter should be unnecessary for right now.)
</panel>

Let's clean up the commit history. Reviews may sometimes involve looking at changes made by going commit by commit in the commit history. To review a PR this way, the PR should only contain the commits relevant to the PR. However, currently, this PR is showing commits from the `arf-instructor-frontend` branch, which is not very relevant to this PR.

![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/65202977/f34a21bd-9883-4fcf-8546-6331f62aba5b)

The following is one possible way to do this. However, you are free to do it in any other way.

```git
git rebase --committer-date-is-author-date --onto <commit SHA of "Add snapshot tests"> <commit SHA of merge>
git rebase --committer-date-is-author-date --onto account-request-form arf-instructor-frontend
```

Here is an explanation, in case you need it. Currently, the overall history, including other branches, looks like the following.

![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/65202977/72da9752-fb9c-469d-a5f6-9b24f5826ae6)

One way to clean the history is to move all the commits from "Add snapshot tests" to "Change double quotes to single quotes" on `arf-instructor-frontend-snap` to branch off of `account-request-form` instead of `arf-instructor-frontend`. You could do this by doing a rebase like the following but the merge commit seems to mess it up.

```git
git rebase --onto account-request-form arf-instructor-frontend
```

1. We can rebase to get rid of the merge commit first by doing the following.

```git
git rebase --onto <commit SHA of "Add snapshot tests"> <commit SHA of merge>
```

2. Then you do the following, like how we originally wanted to.

```git
git rebase --onto account-request-form arf-instructor-frontend
```

By the way, the commands were stated with only the most necessary arguments. Actually, this would result in the rebased commits having a date and time of now, instead of when they were actually made. To prevent this, do the following instead for all the rebase commands.

```git
git rebase --committer-date-is-author-date --onto <branch or commit SHA of new parent commit> <branch or commit SHA of current parent commit>
```
</panel>

You can cherry-pick if you want, but for me, it's less convenient because you need to go commit by commit (you don't feel it now, because there are only a few commits here, but you will feel it if there are a lot), and if I'm not wrong, to keep the original date for the commit, you need to set the date manually. Still, it's up to you.

If you want to cherry-pick, you can do the following.

1. Restart the branch from `account-request-form`.
```git
git reset --hard account-request-form
```
2. Cherry-pick each relevant commit.
```git
git cherry-pick <commit SHA of "Add snapshot tests">
```
```git
git cherry-pick <commit SHA of "Change double quotes to single quotes">
```
</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Apr 02 12:18:16]%%

My concern with this is that the back-end regex and the front-end regex may go out of sync; I think it would probably be better to use the same regex in the front-end as in the back-end. Still, if the one in the back-end cannot be converted then I guess there is nothing much that we can do (that I know of).

One option would be to use your front-end regex in the back-end, but changing the one in the back-end is probably out of our scope (perhaps this can be done after `account-request-form` is merged into `master`). Another option might be to not check this in the front-end at all and just leave this for the back-end to check, but the feedback would probably take longer (requires requests to the server).

In any case, it's probably unlikely that this will go out of sync with the regex in the back-end because it seems it doesn't really change often. For me, I can accept this for now, but let's see if other reviewers want to resolve this and have ideas on how to do so.
</panel>

git rebase --committer-date-is-author-date --onto account-request-form <commit SHA of "Rename methods to be clearer">
```

I think this message may be misleading if the exception is thrown in the if statement when it is handling a batch instead of a single account request.

It is possible for no errors to occur when adding the account requests into the map, but maybe an error may occur when calling `putSqlDocuments` due to something wrong with an account request within the batch (not necessarily the last in the batch). `putSqlDocuments` is only called on the last account request in the batch, so it will produce a message mentioning the last account request in the batch, when in fact the error may have occurred due to another account request in the batch. Maybe the printed stack trace may still somehow indicate this, or maybe no error may even occur, but just in case, maybe we should make this less misleading for tracing purposes.
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/12900" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**198 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #12900: Gradle task componentTests should not stop entirely when only one task fails)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 15 16:17:48]%%

The Gradle task `componentTests` now depends on the two Gradle tasks `unitTests`, and `integrationTests` since #12056. These can be independent from each other, so if one fails, we should continue to execute the other (except when it fails due to the failure of a common dependency, like compilation). However, when either of them fails due to a failing test, the other one is not completed because the execution of the whole `componentTests` task is aborted.

To prevent this, we can run `componentTests` with the option `--continue`, just like the Gradle task `lint`. This probably needs to be changed in the GitHub workflows and in the documentation.
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**207 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #12954: CreateAccountAction seems to have redundant code)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Mar 28 12:23:40]%%

The following code seems to be redundant.

https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/blob/a9423daf0778ca72d0bd71e67ca1ab73e76edb7f/src/main/java/teammates/ui/webapi/CreateAccountAction.java#L114-L115

## Explanation

We obtain the account request from the database, so whatever data it has is already in the database.

https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/blob/a9423daf0778ca72d0bd71e67ca1ab73e76edb7f/src/main/java/teammates/ui/webapi/CreateAccountAction.java#L55

Specifically, the email address, and the institute we get here should be the one already in the database.

https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/blob/a9423daf0778ca72d0bd71e67ca1ab73e76edb7f/src/main/java/teammates/ui/webapi/CreateAccountAction.java#L66-L68

We call this method without having done any changes yet to the account request, the email address, and the institute.

https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/blob/a9423daf0778ca72d0bd71e67ca1ab73e76edb7f/src/main/java/teammates/ui/webapi/CreateAccountAction.java#L95

So it should not be necessary to set the email address, and the institute here. Firstly, the account request already has those values. Secondly, those values are also already in the database.

https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/blob/a9423daf0778ca72d0bd71e67ca1ab73e76edb7f/src/main/java/teammates/ui/webapi/CreateAccountAction.java#L106-L120
</panel>

> Remove this instance from the session cache. Changes to the instance will not be synchronized with the database. This operation cascades to associated instances if the association is mapped with cascade="evict".

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/12708" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**37 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #12708: Use @GenerateValue to automatically generate Id of Entities instead of UUID.randomUUID())
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Jan 27 13:56:15]%%

&lt;!-- Issue title: [brief description of feature/enhancement] -->

**Environment**: &lt;!-- The environment in which the said feature/enhancement is absent, e.g. live server at `V8.0.0`, `master` branch at commit 1234567. -->
v9-migration

**Description of feature/enhancement**
Use @GeneratedValue for entities instead of using UUID.randomUUID() for sql entities. 

For example, 
![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/55353265/81b23b93-c6ab-4bfd-9a4f-6d9ac40b1dd7)
we should add a @GeneratedValue for the @Id field. 

**Justification**
&lt;!-- Explain who will benefit (instructors, students, developers, etc.) and in what way. -->
While there is a low chance of collision using UUID.randomUUID(), there is still a small chance of failure if the random UUID generated in `teammates/src/main/java/teammates/sqllogic/core/DataBundleLogic.java` `persistDataBundle` method. 
![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/55353265/4512bf74-604a-448b-aec8-7c5967e5c8b9)

Instead, a better practice might be to use @GeneratedValue annotation to generate a safe UUID for the respective entities such as `Section`, `Student` etc. 

This would prevent a collision bug from ever occurring. 

</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/12754" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**39 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #12754: Support Hashicorp Terraform for Stage/Prod Environment)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Feb 18 01:58:47]%%

&lt;!-- Issue title: [brief description of feature/enhancement] -->

Could we explore using Terraform to manage our cloud infrastructure? 

**Description of feature/enhancement**

Automate cloud provisioning with Terraform for both staging and prod env. 

**Justification**
&lt;!-- Explain who will benefit (instructors, students, developers, etc.) and in what way. -->

- Terraform allows us to track our infrastructure as code and perform version control. 
- It also allows us to provision and de-provision infra in a single command. 
- It also ensures replicability and ease of setting up future cloud environments (infrastructure variables etc) 
- Hashicorp Vault supports managing of cloud related secrets. 
- Terraform is an all-in-one infrastructure management tool. It does not only support GCP, it supports cloud providers (AWS/Azure), observability platforms such as Grafana etc, providing a single source of truth for all infrastructure used. 
- It can also support Solr setup [Solr for AWS using terraform](https://github.com/edsonmarquezani/terraform-solr-aws)

We could perhaps improve our infra/cloud management experience using Hashicorp terraform. 

- The cons though is that there will be a learning curve to implement this. (Need to learn terraform). 

**Existing similar features and their shortcomings**
&lt;!-- Explain why existing similar features fall short of your expectation. -->
&lt;!-- This section can be skipped if there are no existing similar features. -->

- It can be hard to set up the current staging environments. Current solutions require running multiple commands to set up staging environment using the cloud GUI + gradlew google plugin combination. Leading to tougher infra setup. 
- There isn't a single source of truth for infra setup currently. 
- Lack of version control of infra 
</panel>

<panel type="info" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13055#issuecomment-2064923642" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**40 :octicon-comment:** (commented on issue #13055)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Apr 19 02:48:20]%%

> If it is single threaded application, you mean to say, if there are multiple requests from multiple users, will it not get associated with a thread to complete the task?

Hi there, TEAMMATES does not use multi-threading in the application code in the sense that multiple threads do not perform operations on the same StringBuilder instance in parallel. Hence there is no race condition and no thread-safety is needed.

StringBuffer's thread safety also comes at a cost of slower operations compared to StringBuilder.
</panel>

</panel>

%%[created at: 2024 Feb 18 23:46:42]%%

In the failing test, the function only calls this line, but does not call `frcLogic.updateFeedbackResponseComment(oldResponseComment);`. So, we're expecting only the feedbackResponse to update, but not it's comments. However, in the test right now, the comments are also updated when I call `frDb.updateFeedbackResponse`. This is unintended behavior, as we did not specify the comments to cascade (https://docs.jboss.org/hibernate/orm/6.1/userguide/html_single/Hibernate_User_Guide.html#pc-cascade). 

Right now, I'm still trying to find out why the cascading automatically happens even when we did not state for the cascade to happen. Furthermore, it's an issue as I don't think we're planning for automatic cascade to be intended behavior in the future for performance reasons.
</panel>

@dishenggg @cedricongjh I realized there's also this edge case that might be misleading (probably not as common)

1. Person submitted the responses on 12th April 
2. Query logs from 1st April to 11th April
The message will be "Not submitted responses since Mon, 01 Apr 2024 ... "

I'd rather we display something true, i.e "No access / submitted responses in the query range", or some alternatives that I can think of:

1. Have another action to query the latest logs for each student and display to show either "no submission / access", or the latest submission / access. But I also understand that it's quite close to the release and the action might take a significant amount of work, or
2. Make the end query time to current time permanently, and the current statement will always be true, or
3. Change the message to "No access / submitted responses in the query range".

What do you guys think
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/12758" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**208 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #12758: Resolve mismatch between FeedbackSession and FeedbackSessionAttributes isClosed, isOpened, isInGracePeriod)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Feb 19 17:22:08]%%

Currently, there's a mismatch in behavior of the methods during the migration.
FeedbackSession only takes into account `endTime`, but the original method takes into account `graceTime`, `deadlineExtensions` and `endTime`. 

https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/blob/d6c67fc9dd31c36f196be454a22cce955e1c8229/src/main/java/teammates/storage/sqlentity/FeedbackSession.java#L454-L477

https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/blob/d6c67fc9dd31c36f196be454a22cce955e1c8229/src/main/java/teammates/common/datatransfer/attributes/FeedbackSessionAttributes.java#L318-L344

The actual behavior should instead use these methods:
https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/blob/d6c67fc9dd31c36f196be454a22cce955e1c8229/src/main/java/teammates/storage/sqlentity/FeedbackSession.java#L486-L511

**Impact of bug**
During the migration, due to similarity in names, some migrated actions are utilizing the wrong method. 

**Suggested change**
1. As the `FeedbackSessionAttributes` did not need a separate `isXXXGivenExtendedDeadline` set of methods, a suggestion is to rename them in`FeedbackSession` and make the method signatures match the set of methods in `FeedbackSessionAttributes`.
2. Implement additional unit tests if need be.


</panel>

<hr class="thick-1 border-secondary" />

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/13054" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**209 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #13054: Make substrings of the name in dropdown selections of recipient to be searchable)
</div>

%%[created at: 2024 Apr 18 17:06:46]%%

**Description of feature/enhancement**
![image](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/10182564/c8e361c1-c954-4247-b98c-851b106515f4)

**Context**
When selecting students from a drop-down, there may be many students. If I know the recipient in advance, I would like to quickly type the name from the options and get the selection.

**Problem**
Currently, the code-base supports for searching only if I type the start of the name. 
The problem is when I'm trying to search for a surname, or for example in the screenshot, their first names are prefixed with the section / team names. This makes the search essentially useless.

Being able to search with some sort of substring of the name (all possible substrings, or substrings separated by spaces) will help improve the submission user experience. 
</panel>

Thanks @LarsGielen for the quick changes. Just one last comment on a corner case:

When the user enters 100 characters, they are technically still within the limit (0 characters left), but the search button is disabled. I would suggest either:
- Setting the search button to be disabled when the character count is above the limit (i.e. > 100 characters)
- Removing the disabling of the search button, and introducing an additional check that results in an error message if the character limit is breached

The first option feels cleaner to me since we are, in a sense, "intercepting" input that we know is invalid. The second option is similar to how course copying handles inputs above the character limit.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2023 Jun 28 01:53:41]%%

Perhaps my previous comment was unclear - we're trying to solve overflow (for screen widths >= 360px) while ensuring that styles remain consistent throughout the website as much as possible.

The code block I copied above prevents overflow for smaller screen sizes by setting the `padding-left` and `padding-right` to `.5rem` for screen widths <= 576px. Since this styling is only applied for those screen widths, it also maintains consistency by having the button padding revert back to its original padding.

In contrast, `px-2 px-sm-3` doesn't maintain consistency for larger screen widths since the padding is set to `1 rem` instead of the standard `.75rem`. You can check that this is the case by comparing the buttons to the "Preview as" buttons in the instructor edit session page.

In terms of the clarity of code, I think that adding the extra styling is fine since it's fairly straightforward to see what's going on. Maybe placing it within a class and then applying that to the button would make it clearer, something like:
```
@media (max-width: 576px) ``{``
  // prevent overflow for small screen sizes
  .btn-small-padding ``{``
    padding-left: .5rem;
    padding-right: .5rem;
  ``}``
``}``
```
and then `<button id="btn-copy-question" class="btn btn-primary btn-small-padding"`

Let me know if you disagree. Also taking this chance to ping @domlimm for thoughts and review 
</panel>

Hi @rexong, would it be possible to change it from a word limit to a character limit? Sorry for not pointing this out earlier on the original issue!

The reasoning is:
- The word limit might not prevent the bloating of DB storage since users can enter characters without spaces, and that will still be considered as a single word
- As far as I'm aware, other components use a character limit and not a word limit, so keeping to a character limit would ensure consistency

My apologies again for not flagging this out sooner!

I've also tested out your current solution, and I was able to save a response of over 500 words long... the screenshot below is after saving and refreshing the page:
<img width="1234" alt="Screenshot 2023-07-10 at 8 32 29 PM" src="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/48304907/3ca65eb3-fbb5-44b2-bd94-2707c8c1671c">

As a final comment, do make the changes only to the "Instructions" field in creating and editing a session, as mentioned in the issue. Setting the limit to every single text editor raises several other issues that we probably want to avoid. For example, an instructor might want to set the recommended word count for a question to be 1000 words. However, then students would be unable to hit that recommended word count.

Do let me know if you have any questions about the above.
</panel>

Thanks @rexong for looking into the cause of the issue. I've tried some stuff but am unable to find a solution for the first issue... @domlimm any suggestions? If not, we can open a separate issue for it once this PR gets merged. Should also note that all other formatting (e.g. bold, strikethrough) also gets removed.

For the second part on the truncation of the pasted text, I've done up a quick snippet to see if it's possible:
```
const before = editor.getContent(``{`` format: 'text' ``}``);
setTimeout(() => ``{``
    const currentCharacterCount = this.getCurrentCharacterCount(editor);
    if (currentCharacterCount >= RICH_TEXT_EDITOR_MAX_CHARACTER_LENGTH) ``{``
        event.preventDefault();
        const after = editor.getContent(``{`` format: 'text' ``}``);
        var firstDifferentIndex = 0;
        while (after[firstDifferentIndex] === before[firstDifferentIndex]) ``{``
            ++firstDifferentIndex;
        ``}``
        const left = before.substring(0, firstDifferentIndex);
        const right = before.substring(firstDifferentIndex);
        const pastedTextLength = after.length - before.length;
        const pastedText = after.substring(firstDifferentIndex, firstDifferentIndex + pastedTextLength);
        const amountOver = currentCharacterCount - RICH_TEXT_EDITOR_MAX_CHARACTER_LENGTH;
        const truncatedPastedText = pastedText.substring(0, pastedTextLength - amountOver);
        const finalText = left + truncatedPastedText + right;
        editor.setContent(finalText);
``` 

I ran a couple of tests and it seems to work, @rexong can I leave it to you to make sure that it works with any edge cases as well? I also didn't get to the part on setting the cursor; the cursor should probably be set to the end of the (truncated) pasted text.
</panel>

Hi @singhabhyudita, unfortunately I don't think we should be getting the response rates for all sessions when we populate the table... it will likely cause a huge performance issue, especially given that there might be many sessions ongoing during the range selected.

@Zxun2 has kept the original response rate behaviour by introducing a `cell-with-response-rate` component (`tm-response-rate`) and using that in the `sessions-table` component. When setting the row data of the table,  he calls the `createCellWithResponseRateComponent` (relevant lines: 254 and 293-311) which then creates the `tm-response-rate` component with the original functionality. Note that upon clicking the "Show" button, it triggers the `loadResponseRateEvent` which in turn calls the `loadResponseRateEventHandler` with the relevant index. (@Zxun2 lmk if I got this wrong!)

I think you can try doing something similar here - no need to worry about code duplication for now. Alternatively, you can wait until #12501 gets merged, which I suppose might be about next week since it's a large PR (will get to reviewing it this week).
</panel>

> For the start and end dates I just used the existing enums. On taking a closer look I found out that the `SESSION_START_DATE` and `SESSION_END_DATE` are being sorted lexicographically in the table-comparator service file.

You're right that they are being sorted lexicographically; however, the underlying data is being stored as a number (timestamp) rather than the string. Hence, when sorted, the numbers are compared which produces the correct result. You can see this in action by going to the `compareLexicographically` method of the `table-comparator.service.ts` and logging `strA` and `strB`. When the admin sessions table is sorted, they output a date string; when say the sessions table in the instructor home page is sorted, they output a number representing the date.

My suggestion is to take a closer look at how the sessions table in the instructor home page is handled, including the `createDateCellWithToolTip` which you'll see transforms the timestamp (a number) into the string value to be displayed to the user. Some changes will probably be needed to be made to the `OngoingSessionsModel` (which I'm not sure why is defined in the response rate cell component... would have thought leaving it in the admin sessions page component would be better). I think now only the string is stored - either store both, or only store the `endTime`/`startTime` and then convert it to a string later on.

</panel>

> Hello @weiquu, This is my first time contributing to a open source and accidentally committed the `package-lock.json `. I have a quick question should I be raising a PR to fix the previous PR or should I just raise new PR with just the changes in it?

The best approach would be to revert the `package-lock.json` to the previous commit (i.e. the one on the `master` branch). There are a couple of resources online of how to do so using git, for example [here](https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/git-revert-file-reverting-a-file-to-a-previous-commit/) and [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/215718/how-can-i-reset-or-revert-a-file-to-a-specific-revision). I would strongly suggest using this approach, since it will get you more familiar with git and will likely be useful in your future software development.

Of course, if you're unable to, you can always close this PR and open a new one with the same changes (without committing the `package-lock.json` file). However, please try the above approach first.
</panel>

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/12657" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**383 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #12657: Instructor Home Page: Students dropdown buttons of the wrong colour)
</div>

%%[created at: 2023 Dec 12 20:52:01]%%

The buttons in the Students dropdown of a course in the instructor home page are the wrong colour:

![Screenshot 2023-12-12 at 8 36 41 PM](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/48304907/7c01e3d6-f6c0-4e32-8034-9169ad873d47)

This seems to be an unintentional change cause by #12591, in particular the following addition to `styles.scss`:
```
  .btn-info ``{``
    background-color: darken(#0DCAF0, 3%); // 3% darker than info
  ``}``
```

The background colour is being used by another button in another page; moreover, it's unclear why the buttons in the students dropdown is of class `.btn-info` when no other dropdown button has that class (they have `.button-light` instead, but even that class seems to be redudant).

<panel type="warning" popup-url="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/issues/12669" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**397 :octicon-issue-opened:** (created issue #12669: More guidance for updating of snapshot tests)
</div>

%%[created at: 2023 Dec 17 04:37:58]%%

Fairly often I've found myself (and seen others) commenting the following text (or something similar) on PRs:

> You can update the snapshots by running `npm run test` and pressing `a` to run all test cases. After that, check through the snapshots to make sure the changes are as expected, then press `u` to update them. You can find more details on snapshot testing [here](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/snapshot-testing.html).

The frequency of this issue's occurrence points to it being a problem with our documentation (or possibly something workflow related) rather than with individual contributors.

I've gone through the dev docs, and the sections relevant to snapshot tests are:
- Development -&gt; Testing -&gt; [Running the tests](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/development.html#testing), which doesn't really mention how to update tests. It's also worth mentioning that if `npm run test` is ran after changes are made (which I find is often the case in my own development), sometimes no tests are ran at all, giving the impression that there are no changes needed to tests
- [Snapshot Testing](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/snapshot-testing.html), which mentions the default verification mode and how the auto-update mode is activated by pressing `u`

Unfortunately, the link between the 2 pages is not made explicit - the first doesn't mention snapshot testing, and the second doesn't mention the `npm run test` command.

My suggestion is to amend the docs such that this process is made clearer. For example, we could amend the Development page to link the snapshot tests to the command (and options), as well as add in a point to the Process page, which the generated PR description points to. Even just a paragraph mentioning the text (see above) would be useful, so that we could give contributors the link to it.

Possibly a checklist of test commands to run in the PR description would also be helpful, though I seem to remember some reservations about making the PR description too long.
</panel>

%%[created at: 2023 Oct 30 18:50:52]%%

> However, are we actually certain that this is the actual cause of the issue?

Yes, this is due to the session cache in Objectify (https://github.com/objectify/objectify/wiki/Caching):

<img width="917" alt="image" src="https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/assets/67156011/47a9930d-ad56-40ea-911f-0c9a4092f3f2">

In particular, "The session cache holds your specific entity object instances. If you load() the same entity, you will receive the exact same Java entity object instance"

Hence, when updating the student deadlines in the current code, while the java entity object changes, the test case passes, as it is not fetching the entity from the db, rather it is using the current cached entity that was loaded previously, whose student deadlines were updated, but not saved to the db. 

To make the test case fail with the current code, I added Objectify.clear(); between the loading of the old and new feedback sessions.

Moreover, testing on the frontend on this branch does resolve the issue.

</panel>

```
const inputElement = fixture.debugElement.query(By.css('#max-value')).nativeElement as HTMLInputElement;
inputElement.value = 'abc';
expect(inputElement.value).toBe('')

inputElement.value = '2333';
expect(inputElement.value).toBe('2333')

```

Do try it out and let me know if it works!
</panel>
